entry.title: Preliminary What’s New Information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502.3
entry.content:
Preliminary versions of What’s New information and of the Product Assistance are now available for customers and partners to get a preview on the upcoming new and changed features of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502.3.

You can find this preview on the current Help Portal page SAP S/4HANA Cloud (see What’s New section “Preview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2502.3”). To access the Preliminary What’s New information, please use the What’s New Viewer or the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool.

The RASD tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What’s New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The preliminary information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2502.3 will be available in RASD within the next few days. We recommend using RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you. A valid S-User ID is needed to use the RASD tool and to view all the preliminary content stated above.

For any feedback you may have, try the Commenting Feature for What's New documentation in this release. See this blog for more information.

entry.title: Optimize SAP ECC Licenses and User Classification Independently with Accelerator for SAM4U
entry.content:
Introduction

Many SAP customers find value in the extended reporting capabilities provided by the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption (available on the SAP Store) - especially for S/4HANA license management and optimization. However, what about customers who are still operating SAP ECC and plan to do so for several more years? These organizations are still subject to SAP audits and need effective tools for managing and optimizing their SAP ECC licenses.

Let’s explore how Accelerator for SAM4U can also support SAP ECC customers in preparing for SAP audits and optimizing their current license usage.

Analyze Current Classification vs. Authorization-Based Classification

There is no direct mapping between SAP ECC named user license metrics and S/4HANA ruleset metrics. Still, it’s crucial to focus on high-cost license types, such as Professional and Limited Professional users, to unlock potential savings.

For example, in one customer case, the SAP ECC license usage looked like this:

  • 52 Professional Users

  • 53 Limited Professional Users

Using the Authorization Analysis feature of SAM4U’s extended reporting and simulation, we can map users' current manual classifications against their actual usage potential - based on their roles and profiles in the SAP ECC system. This gives insight into what kind of system footprint a user is authorized to leave, aligning more closely with S/4HANA’s licensing logic.

Example: Reclassifying Professional Users

 Pic. 1 – Current Classification vs. Authorization-Based Classification

Let’s focus on the 52 Professional Users:

  • Only 101 users truly have professional roles (mapped to the HB Professional User metric in S/4HANA).

  • 126 users currently classified as Professional Users have roles corresponding only to an HC Functional footprint. These users can be considered, roughly, as 53 Limited Professional Users.

Instead of analyzing each user in the HC Functional group in detail (which is time-consuming), the extended reporting for SAM4U dashboard allows you to drill down and extract a list of these 126 users with a single click. This list can then be sent to your SAP system administrator to update their license metric accordingly.

 Pic. 2 – Users to Reclassify from 52 Professional to 53 Limited Professional

Additionally, there are 184 users classified as 52 Professional Users whose assigned roles do not match any classification in the S/4HANA ruleset.

For these, we recommend mapping them to 59 Core Users - a more cost-effective metric in SAP ECC for unclassified users.

 Pic. 3 – Users to Reclassify from 52 Professional to 59 Core

This rough reclassification already opens up a path to significant license cost savings by reducing the number of users under the expensive 52 Professional Users metric.

Identify Missing Upgrades: Core Users Who Should Be Professional

The final step in this license "homework" is to identify users who are underclassified - those listed as 59 Core Users in SAP ECC, but whose roles match HB Professional in the S/4HANA ruleset.

These users may need to be upgraded to 52 Professional Users to ensure compliance and avoid audit risk. Again, this can be done easily through the drill-down functionality in SAM4U’s reporting dashboard.

 Pic. 4 – Users to Reclassify from 59 Core to 52 Professional

Conclusion

The extended reporting and simulation provided by the Accelerator for SAM4U offers powerful, independent insights into your SAP ECC user classifications. By comparing current user classifications with authorization-based projections (using S/4HANA rulesets), you can:

  • Optimize license allocation

  • Identify over- and under-classified users

  • Prepare confidently for SAP audits

  • Uncover significant cost-saving opportunities

You can request free demo access to the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption tenant from SAP Store to explore these features and validate your own SAP ECC user classification strategy.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Workflow, Situation Handling, KPIs, etc
entry.content:
TL;DR – Know when to use which SAP Fiori notifications.  That is, workflow versus situation handling versus Smart Business KPI subscriptions versus process-specific notifications, and which technique to use if you need to create clean core custom notifications.  

A very common business requirement is to notify someone that something has happened and, if possible, get them started on responding to it. 

  • In classic SAP ECC you would use typically workflow notifications and/or email notifications. Unfortunately, over time this often led to a flood of emails, emails being ignored, and increasingly poor response times.
  • In SAP S/4HANA there are a range of more useful, more nuanced, notification techniques available in SAP Fiori that encourage prompt action. You can optionally send them as push notifications to your tablet or phone. These notifications don’t flood your email inbox, however if you want email notifications, you can optionally echo selected notifications to email.

These notifications are deliberately difficult to miss! You will find your notifications in a variety of places, including the notification center of the SAP Fiori launchpad as shown in the example below: 

Why this blog series?  During workshops with one my recent customers currently in transition to SAP S/4HANA, we came across a point of confusion. They are very interested in using Situation Handling but were getting confused about when to use Situation Handling versus Workflow versus some other notification technique. In this blog you will find the different notification techniques explained and when to use them. 

There is a quick summary of the SAP Fiori notification techniques discussed in this blog post in the image below. These techniques are also listed in the table later in this blog post in section SAP Notification Techniques in SAP S/4HANA and when to use them.

In this first blog post, you will learn:

  • Part 1 - SAP Fiori notification techniques available in SAP S/4HANA and when to use them; when to use email notifications to complement or supplement SAP Fiori notifications. 

Later in this blog series you will learn:

  • Part 2 - The impact on business users: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Impact on business users   

In part 2 you will learn where notifications are visible in the SAP Fiori launchpad of SAP S/4HANA and elsewhere such as: SAP Fiori app F0862 My Inbox, SAP Fiori app F6511 My Outbox, SAP Fiori app F4154 My Situations, SAP Fiori app F4537 My Situations - Extended, SAP Build Work Zone,  SAP Task Center, SAP Mobile Start, and elsewhere.

You will also look under the covers at what your team needs to do to enable notifications.

  • Part 3 - For Key Users, Functional Consultants and UX Architects: Where & how to configure each notification technique in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Where and how to configure
  • Part 4 - For Administrators and Developers, understand prerequisites such as the technical notification channel and notification provider that drives predefined and custom notification techniques, what's involved in setting up predefined notifications versus custom notifications, and some FAQ and Troubleshooting tips in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Notifications for Admins and Developers

Further references: 

  • For the difference between classic workflows, flexible workflows, and related cloud workflow techniques in SAP BTP refer to SAP Help - ABAP Platform - Workflow
  • For the difference between workflow and situations, and the difference between standard vs extended situations, refer to SAP Help – SAP S/4HANA – Process Management and Integration – Situation Handling - FAQ.
  • For understanding Smart Business KPIs refer to SAP Help - SAP S/4HANA - Analytics - Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
  • Although much has changed, there is still some useful background information in our earlier blog post SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Notification Center - Part 1 - Activation 

 

SAP Notification Techniques in SAP S/4HANA and when to use them

In the table below, you will find the 4 main SAP Fiori notification techniques to choose from based on your use case.

Use Case

Example

Notification Technique

Configured By

Notify an approver they have an approvals task

Notify approver of a new Purchase Order requiring their approval

Workflow notifications - flexible workflow (preferred) or classic workflow (supported)

Key User or UX Architect

Notify a business expert of a business situation to be resolved

 

Notify someone that: a contract is about to expire; a batch job has failed with a business-critical error, etc.

Situation Handling notifications - standard or extended

Key User or UX Architect

Notify that a KPI will soon be/has been exceeded target threshold

Notify the responsible manager that actual budget has reached 90% of planned budget

Smart Business KPI notifications

Key User or Analytics Specialist

Notify someone that a process has completed successfully

Notify Purchaser of the number of PRs automatically converted to POs today

Process-specific notifications

Administrator 

When choosing between these notification types the main factors to consider are:

  • Traceability – Where you have very strict highly-controlled processes – such as approvals (also known as delegations of authority) - workflow notifications provide end-to-end traceability of every step of the process. You can find the status of the approval at any time and have an audit trail history (via the workflow log) of what has occurred including who was involved in each task.
  • Productivity – When working with business experts, you want them to know a business situation has happened and to be supported in how to resolve the business situation.  However, you don’t want the business expert to feel micro-managed as that could make them less productive and even impact their mental health!  Situation handling is the right choice here to aid swift resolution while showing that you trust the business expert to take the appropriate action. You can find the status of the situation’s business object at any time, which situation type was triggered, and which team was involved. The user acting on the business object is deliberately not tracked by the situation, however if they have made a change to a business object that will be tracked, as usual, in the change log history of the relevant business object.
  • Expected Response –
    • Workflow notifications require a strict response – for example, the approver must approve or reject a purchase order. 
    • Situation notifications require a flexible response, the business expert must decide what is the appropriate action to take to resolve the situation.
    • Most other notifications – both Smart Business KPIs and process-specific notifications – are primarily about keeping people informed with no specific response needed.
  • Notification source – To make sure the recipient is notified as quickly as possible, it makes sense to trigger the notification from the workflow, situation, KPI or process that first identifies the need for the notification. 
    • Often there are predefined notification providers that provide easy options to configure & trigger these notifications.  
    • Where you don’t have a predefined notification provider, creating a custom notification provider is a relatively easy task for a developer, and worth considering.

 

Understanding the Effort required to Configure Notifications

Skills needed for configuring all predefined notification use cases are LOW. 

Creating your own custom notifications is a LOW to MEDIUM effort for a Developer with a small amount of configuration required by an Administrator.

 

When to use email notifications instead of SAP Fiori notifications

There are 2 additional notification use cases that commonly occur. While they may seem like separate notification types, they are essentially just variations of the notification types listed above. In these cases, an email notification is more likely to be required. These also are LOW effort to configure. 

 

Use Case

Example

How to Handle

Configured By

Notify a casual employee that something has occurred

Notify a user who doesn’t login very often

 

User needs to login at least to the SAP Fiori launchpad. They can go to their personal Settings & opt to echo notifications to email. That is, in the User Actions > Settings > Notifications area. They can only configure notification types they have received at least once.

Business User

Notify an external person that something has occurred

 

Notify a supplier that a quote has been accepted

 

In this situation, the external person does not have access to the SAP Fiori launchpad.  Where needed, notifications to external suppliers are typically included in process-specific notifications. 

Key User or Functional Consultant

 

Sending aggregated email notifications of SAP Fiori notifications

For notifications where a response is expected, you may want to notify the user by multiple channels.

For workflow notifications the Workflow Extended Notifications (program SWN_SELSEN) is still available and can be scheduled as a batch program. You configure workflow extended notifications transactions SWN_CONFIG and SWNADMIN. You can include a link to SAP Fiori app F0862 My Inbox in the email.

Hint: To minimize searching through emails for past notifications, you should consider adding app F6511 My Outbox to all users who have My Inbox. My Outbox enables users to view the workflow log and task log of workflows they have been involved in, allowing them to see what happened before/after their involvement.

For situations, in app F2947 Manage Situation Types or F5437 Manage Situation Types – Extended, you can configure the option to send an email for aggregated notifications.

Refer to

  • SAP Help – ABAP Platform – SAP Business Workflow Reference Documentation - Extended Notifications for SAP Business Workflow
  • SAP Note 2892592 - WF Notifications: Generate link to My Inbox
  • SAP Note 3589593 - Setting Up Workflow Extended Notification Mail for Specific Multiple Recipients
  • SAP Help – SAP S/4HANA – Process Management and Integration - Situation Handling - Notifications

 

Notification techniques to avoid

Avoid using classic SAP Business Workflow “Display Notification” Tasks  - i.e. Task Type = Notification. These classic notifications are only visible in the classic SAP Office Inbox and have very limited features.

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You’ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

entry.title: New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers
entry.content:
Good news for creators! The SAP Fiori design guidelines site is now the SAP Design System portal. The new portal is your one-stop-shop to find everything about the design system. And that’s not all: we have released comprehensive new UI Kits for designers in Figma, the tool used by designers around the world.

 

SAP Design System Portal

The new SAP Design System portal brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. Bringing these all together is not the only improvement we’ve made, we have also:

  • Enhanced usability: easier to navigate and find what you need.
  • Improved performance: much faster page load times.
  • Simplified versioning: the 50+ guideline versions of the past for SAP Fiori for web have now been consolidated into six versions, corresponding to the six versions of SAPUI5 which are in long-term maintenance.
  • Product specific content: in addition to content which is applicable everywhere, we now also make it clear when content applies only to specific products, for example due to dependencies to product-specific technologies. At the moment we have one such section in the portal, for SAP S/4HANA (which also covers SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private).
  • Feedback button: you can now give us direct feedback on the content, via the feedback button available on the bottom right of each page (as you can see in Figure 1).

SAP’s digital design system reflects our evolved brand and is aligned to our product design system. It serves as a reference for all who contribute content to our public-facing web sites.

Figure 1: The SAP Design System portal start page. Alt Text: Image with header saying “SAP Design System”, with a “See what’s new” button below it, and then four subsections in a horizontal row: SAP Fiori for Web, SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for iOS and SAP’s Digitial Design System. A “Feedback” button is on the bottom right.

Have a look at this 45 second video to get an overview:

 

 

UI Kits for Designers

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

In addition, we give you design resources for designing for accessibility and for performance.

Figure 2: SAP’s UI Kits for Designers in Figma. Alt-Text: The image shows two rows of three cards representing UI Kits: SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for Web, Designing for Performance, SAP Fiori for iOS, SAP Fiori for watchOS, and SAP Fiori for Wear OS. On the very left of the image information about SAP is listed, with links to resources such as www.sap.com/design-system.

Get an overview and see how easy it is for designers to put together a new UI in this 43 second video:

 

 

User Experience in SAP Community

I’m looking forward to seeing how you like the new SAP Design System portal and the new UI Kits for Designers. Do use the SAP Community to exchange your ideas and best practices by using the “User Experience” tag.

Here is a link to the latest posts for User Experience.

For an overview of design at SAP, check out www.sap.com/design.

entry.title: SAP User Experience in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502
entry.content:
January 24 marked the general availability of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 release. As a cornerstone of modern enterprise, SAP Business Suite empowers organizations to scale, innovate, and adapt faster than ever. SAP cloud ERP applications, SAP Business AI, and SAP Business Data Cloud come together to deliver exceptional business value. But even the most robust cloud ERP wouldn't reach its full potential without a smooth user experience. That’s why we’re committed to evolving our product, listening to your feedback, and pushing the boundaries to deliver a user experience that matches the pace of today's dynamic work environment. Let me show you just how we achieve this in this release. Honorary mention: Generative AI is giving main character energy in this release.

Check out my video below to get a first glimpse into what’s coming in the area of SAP User Experience in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502:

 

Joule, the AI Copilot

Following a successful early adoption phase, Joule is generally available and fully integrated in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This AI copilot utilizes generative AI to help users complete tasks more efficiently by using natural language to express their business needs. It offers quick navigation to applications, instant insights into key business data like purchase orders, and concise user enablement content to speed up tasks. Joule also simplifies personalization of the My Home section, allowing users to create cards with critical data for immediate insights. Its capabilities include recommending relevant applications, providing insightful information on business situations without needing to open the application, and offering brief summaries of help content. Users can directly create and add preview cards to the Insights section of My Home.

 

 

AI-Assisted Smart Summarization

AI-assisted smart summarization allows you to summarize object pages of SAP Fiori elements-based applications with the power of generative AI. The summarization can be reviewed and modified in a rich text editor and easily copied into productivity tools, such as email or chat, for follow-ups with co-workers and customers. The tool also facilitates efficient sharing through seamless copy-to-clipboard functionality for quick follow-ups. Additionally, users have the option to provide feedback on their experience with the feature, contributing to its continual improvement and adaptation to user needs.

 

 

AI-Assisted Easy Filter

The AI-assisted easy filter leverages state-of-the-art generative AI to redefine how users approach filtering within SAP Fiori elements-based list reports. Rather than setting filter values manually through type-ahead inputs and value helps, you can simply type your search query into the filter field. This approach not only enhances the user experience but also provides easy access to recent and favorite filter queries. The AI results are reliable, offering an intuitive and click-efficient experience, which is particularly beneficial for new users navigating the system.

 

 

Currently in Beta Testing: AI-Assisted Easy Enterprise Search

The AI-assisted easy enterprise search leverages generative AI to enable natural language querying for business objects throughout the solution. By simply typing your search query into the search field of the SAP Fiori launchpad, users can quickly access the information they need. This feature is especially valuable for its time-saving capabilities when searching with known criteria, providing reliable AI results and offering an intuitive, click-efficient experience that benefits new users in particular.

Register here to start testing: Newest AI-assisted user experience features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Currently in Beta Testing: AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home

The AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home allows you to use natural language through the power of generative AI to add insights cards to your My Home experience. This feature streamlines the process by enabling you to add insights cards directly from My Home with just two clicks, including a preview step for the end-user to review the AI-generated result. This tool offers several benefits, such as saving time when adding insights cards, providing better insights into business data, and delivering reliable AI results. It is designed to be intuitive and click-efficient, making it especially valuable for new users.

Register here to start testing: Newest AI-assisted user experience features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Currently in Beta Testing: AI-Assisted Error Explanation

AI-assisted error explanation supports in understanding errors in SAP Fiori elements-based applications better and provides first recommendations on how to solve the errors by leveraging the power of generative AI. This innovative feature is seamlessly integrated into the current error visualization, enabling users to generate explanations on demand, which significantly saves time and improves workflow efficiency. By offering intuitive navigation, it delivers both the explanatory insight and recommended solutions within a single, click-efficient action. The process includes well-structured results that clarify the nature of the error and suggest practical resolutions.

Register here to start testing: Newest AI-assisted user experience features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Interested in all things AI? Read this blog posts by my colleagues Yannick Peterschmitt and Sang Dao:

  • Artificial Intelligence and Other Intelligent ERP Use Cases in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502
  • Artificial Intelligence & Technologies in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502

 

To-Dos in Microsoft Teams Integration

The integration of To-Dos in Microsoft Teams allows users to seamlessly access their workflow items from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition directly through the SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Microsoft Teams app. When you receive a workflow item in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, it triggers a notification in Microsoft Teams. This integration enables you to open the My Inbox application from Microsoft Teams to view details of the workflow items and to take immediate action. It also supports mobile approvals, ensuring flexibility in managing workflows on the go.

 

Smart Heads-Up of Situations in To Dos

Smart heads-up in To Dos ensure that you're always up to speed on situations requiring your attention, allowing you to manage all critical matters efficiently. This feature provides immediate insight and actionability through an intuitive interface, ensuring that nothing important slip through the cracks. By staying informed about and addressing potential issues early on, it significantly boosts productivity. Additionally, it offers support in prioritizing actions effectively. Users can get an overview of situations on both the standard and extended frameworks directly in the To-Dos section. With just one click, they can access detailed information by navigating to the My Situations and My Situations – Extended apps, depending on their needs.

 

As you can see, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 not only promises a transformed user experience but also enhances organizational productivity and strategic decision-making, bringing you closer to achieving seamless operational excellence, rooted in innovative technology.

Find out more about SAP User Experience in the numerous blog posts by my colleagues Thomas Reiss and Conrad Bernal.

entry.title: Parallel universes: the dual nature of UX and AI among SAP customers at Sapphire 2025
entry.content:
Sapphire 2025 was interesting and revealing. In the keynotes, theater sessions, and ASUG breakouts, SAP experts and executives talked about the latest innovations around artificial intelligence (AI), data, and user experience (UX). The customer questions and survey responses, however, revealed a parallel universe. Many organizations are on such old systems that they are not able to consume SAP’s cool new functionality. In this post, I will discuss some of my observations, based on conversations with customers and partners, and share some polling I did in one of my sessions on the intersection between SAP Fiori and AI. I will also include links to several slide decks, recorded demos, and on-demand sessions where you can dive deeper into UX and AI topics.

Customers are starting to use AI, but still behind on SAP Fiori UX adoption

In ERP1612, “Enhancing User Experience with SAP Fiori and AI”, I asked the audience of around 120 people how they are using AI in their companies. 96 people responded.

 

The 56% percent of the people who are using AI in some way is a big jump from the 37% who responded at ASUG Tech Connect last fall. The main topic in both sessions was SAP Fiori, so the audience profile should be somewhat similar, although the Tech Connect attendees might be more technical as opposed to the business focus at Sapphire.

View the slides from ERP1612.

https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/key/1T0gHqRT6X9ddr?hostedIn=slideshare&page=upload

The central theme was SAP Fiori, so it made sense to level set on where people are on their adoption journey. My expectations were high since SAP Fiori has been available since 2013. Since then, our team has spent many hours talking to 1000s of customers and partners about building SAP Fiori apps and how to streamline the process using our tools and technologies such as SAP Fiori elements, SAP Fiori tools, and new AI accelerators.

But, the reality was very different. Only 9 of 109 respondents are using SAP Fiori across their organizations. 43% are still in the planning stage.

 

 

To help customers move to SAP Business Suite, we had many sessions. One that’s available on demand is “Embark on a successful transformation journey to SAP Business Suite,” featuring Maura Hameroff, Priyadarsana Panda, and Soeren Ruder.

Arpan Shah describes how SAP Business Suite drives transformational value through the suite’s strength and software-as-a-service qualities with integrated processes, data, and AI in the on-demand session “Leverage the benefits of SAP Business Suite in your cloud strategy.”

There were some nice demos of the latest SAP user experience in “SAP's user experience strategy to achieve better outcomes” by Arin Bhowmik and Emil Voutta.

Tom Reiss also had some great sessions on SAP Fiori innovations with nice demos, but unfortunately, they were not recorded.

Dr. Tom Reiss before his session.

AI in SAP Cloud ERP wowed the crowd

In Chris Hoffmann’s session, BAI1362, which I heard several people say was the best talk of the entire Sapphire, he showed several key innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Here are the slides and demos from his presentation:

  • Slides in PDF format
  • Insights card creation with Joule
  • AI-assisted easy filter
  • AI-assisted smart summarization
  • AI-assisted error explanation
  • AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home
  • SAP Fiori elements Project Accelerator

Chris Hoffmann during his talk about adding AI to SAP Fiori apps at both design time and runtime

Several executives from SAP and our customers discussed how AI is transforming business. See their session “Harness the benefits of data and AI in ERP and drive innovation” on demand.

For a bigger picture view on where these AI innovations fit into the broader SAP Business Suite, watch “Transform your enterprise with the power of SAP Business Suite.”

SAP Sapphire is a great place for discovery

The new (to SAP) harmonized product operating model focuses on discovery. Interacting with customers to understand their needs plays a big role for product managers and everyone involved in the development process. Sapphire and the after-hours events provide a great venue for conversations with customers about the problems they want to solve.

Since I’m known for my interest in user experience topics, most of my meetings and questions in my sessions focused on UX and adjacent topics. One of my goals was to gather feedback on what we show and address questions about what people need. While people seemed to like the new AI functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition that Chris and I showed in our respective sessions, the most common question was when it is coming to private cloud (planned) and on-prem (not planned).

There were several sessions on organizational change management, which seemed to be one of the main reasons that people have not migrated off the SAP GUI, even though they like to complain about it. Some of the main takeaways from the OCM panel were:

  • Prioritize people not technology
  • Change management takes a toll on people – prep for the after.
  • Don’t lose sight of the goal and decommission the old technology. Make sure to listen and be agile.
  • The journey will be difficult, acknowledge this and over-communicate.

I really enjoyed Paul Saunders’ entertaining and informative sessions on “Leveraging dark data for enhanced decision-making” and “Antifragile enterprises: How true resilience comes from embracing change.” These too were not recorded.

The panel on antifragile enterprises: How true resilience comes from embracing change

Too much content; too little time

Content overload was a common theme I heard from many of the people I spoke with at Sapphire. There were so many sessions crammed into the compressed 2-day format (compared to three days in years past).

BTP remained a hot topic, with many people looking to understand the best way to obtain value.

Discover SAP Business Technology Platform and its value for your business is a good overview on this.

Another good BTP session is “Unleash the power of your applications, data, and AI with SAP BTP.”

AI everywhere – separating reality from hype

AI was top of mind for everyone as it played such a major role in the keynotes. The most common issues that people raised with me were:

  • Concerns about privacy of their data
  • How much of the capability is real and can the results be trusted?
  • Availability of AI functionality outside of SAP Cloud ERP and the associated costs

SAP Sapphire is all about the people

It was great to meet several colleagues in person for the first time and to connect with those that I see only a few times each year.

If we did not meet at Sapphire and you are interested in joining the conversation about SAP Fiori application development and how AI makes it better, faster, and cheaper, please join our monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable group or sign up for our bi-monthly newsletter.

For the UX Foundation team, Peter Spielvogel.

entry.title: Create Button Styles in SAP Analytics Cloud stories
entry.content:
Intro

In SAP Analytics Cloud stories you have the possibility to add a button widget to your story.
In this blog I want to show you how you can create centrally maintained button styles to achieve a consistent button styling with different button styles for your story.

 

Use Case

In our example use case we want to create the following different button styles:

  • Standard
  • Emphasized
  • Lite
  • Accept
  • Reject
  • Attention

Buttons: Standard, Emphasized, Lite

Buttons: Accept, Reject, Attention

Based on your company’s design system you can add additional button styles or define less button styles.

 

Solution

In SAP Analytics Cloud we only have on generic widget of the type “button” available. Therefore, to create different button styles we can use the CSS feature. For each button style we create a CSS class with a meaningful name that we can later use in the styling panel to apply the specific button widget.

Here is an example for a standard button that shows the CSS structure:

.button--standard .sap-custom-button{
	color: #0064d9;
	background-color: #FFFFFF;
	border-color: #BCC3CA;
	border-radius: 8px;
}
.button--standard .sap-custom-button:hover{
	color: #0064d9;
	background-color: #eaecee;
	border-color: #BCC3CA;	
}
.button--standard .sap-custom-button:active{
	color: #0064d9;
	background-color: #ffffff;
	border-color: #0064D9;	
}

To apply the button style to the button widget all you need to do is to write the custom CSS class name into the CSS Input Field of the Styling Panel.

Button Styling with CSS Infographic

 

 

Further Considerations

To use these button styles across several stories, you can upload the CSS to a Story Theme. You can then use the custom CSS classes in all Stories that are using this Story Theme.

 

Ready to use CSS Example

Here is a ready to use CSS snippet that contains all the button styles outlined at the beginning of the blog.
Paste this CSS into the Story CSS Editor and start using these button styles or adapt the color values to apply your own branding from your design system.

/**Standard Button - .button--standard class**/
.button--standard .sap-custom-button{
	color: #0064d9;
	background-color: #FFFFFF;
	border-color: #BCC3CA;
	border-radius: 8px;
}
.button--standard .sap-custom-button:hover{
	color: #0064d9;
	background-color: #eaecee;
	border-color: #BCC3CA;	
}
.button--standard .sap-custom-button:active{
	color: #0064d9;
	background-color: #ffffff;
	border-color: #0064D9;	
}

/**Emphasized Button - .button--emphasized class**/
.button--emphasized .sap-custom-button{
    color:#FFFFFF;
    background-color:#0070F2;
    border-color: #0070F2;
	border-radius: 8px; 
}
.button--emphasized .sap-custom-button:hover{
    color:#FFFFFF;
    background-color:#0064d9;
    border-color:#0064d9;
}
.button--emphasized .sap-custom-button:active{
    color:#0064d9;
    background-color:#ffffff;
    border-color:#0064d9;
}

/*Lite Button - .button--lite class*/
.button--lite .sap-custom-button{
    color:#0064D9;
    background-color:transparent;
    border-color:transparent;
	border-radius:8px;
}
.button--lite .sap-custom-button:hover{
    color:#0064D9;
    background-color:#EAECEE;
    border-color:#BCC3CA;
}
.button--lite .sap-custom-button:active{
    color:#0064D9;
    background-color:#ffffff;
    border-color:#0064D9;
}

/**Accept Button/ Confirm / Positiv - .button--accept class**/
.button--accept .sap-custom-button{
    color:#256F3A;
    background-color:#EBF5CB;
    border-color: #DBEDA1;
	border-radius:8px;
}
.button--accept .sap-custom-button:hover{
    color:#256F3A;
    background-color:#e3f1b6;
    border-color:#e3f1b6;
}
.button--accept .sap-custom-button:active{
    color:#256F3A;
    background-color:#ffffff;
    border-color:#30914C;
}

/* Reject Button */
.button--reject .sap-custom-button{
    color:#AA0808;
    background-color:#FFD6E9;
    border-color:#ffc1df;
	border-radius:8px;
}
.button--reject .sap-custom-button:hover{
    color:#AA0808;
    background-color:#ffbcdc;
    border-color:#ffc1df;
}
.button--reject .sap-custom-button:active{
    color:#AA0808;
    background-color:#ffffff;
    border-color: #E90B0B;
}

/* Attention Button */
.button--attention .sap-custom-button{
    color:#b44f00;
    background-color:#FFF3B7;
    border-color:#FFEA84;
	border-radius:8px;
}
.button--attention .sap-custom-button:hover{
    color:#b44f00;
    background-color:#FFEF9E;
    border-color:#FFEF9E;
}
.button--attention .sap-custom-button:active{
    color:#b44f00;
    background-color:#ffffff;
    border-color: #DD6100;
}

entry.title: Creation of Deep Links in SuccessFactors Suites
entry.content:
📢What is Deep Link ?  📢 It is a hyperlink that helps the system users / those newly experiencing the system for the first time to navigate to the precise target location of user Information/company Information out of the crowded system details, so you will not be lost. You can place this link anywhere on your company website / Emails / external systems by clicking on it will drive you to the desired location, even in the SuccessFactors home page (tiles/cards) or in the main navigation menu.

🗣🔊What does 1H-2025 say on the Deep link for those who opted (PPX UI Experience) - SAP recommend that to configure deep links to cards or categories and stop using legacy block deep links in your system. Currently, only certain block deep links containing block types can be resolved for the latest People Profile.

PP3 UI (Legacy People Profile Experience)

PPX UI (Latest People Profile)

BLOCKS

Categories

Portlets

Summary Cards

 

👨‍🏫What are all the Data elements that comprise forming complete Deep links? 

1.Domain Name - Name used by the application server, you can make use of this information from the browser URL, (Tip – Make use of data before “/”), and it varies by customer and region (https://hcm-eu10-sales.hr.cloud.sap)

2.Deep link Path 🛣 – True deep links begin with “/sf/” and deep link paths are the first filter and navigation definition of the data/location, where the user would like to navigate to. Deep link would vary based on the location/destination/sf-module of the data where we need to land the user. Currently, we are exploring the employee profile information, so our Deep link path would be “sf/liveprofile”.

Tip 💡 – We can’t define the Deep link path on our own, it was pre-defined by the SAP for the different modules and based on the nature of data where the deep link is supported, please find the link for more Deep Link path on your business requirement SAP Help Portal - Deep Links

3.Parameters – After Deep Link path, parameters which help for the fine-granular navigation refinement with the help of data (i.e. Key value pair) which directs the user to the destination page where we are expecting the user to land 🛬. Also, the parameter values vary based on the nature of the data we are trying to land  🛬.

  • CategoryId = personalData , jobData , compensation
  • cardId = personalInfo, jobInfo , oneTimePayment
  • username= John123

 

4.Separators – There are different separators based on the nature of the parameters we are trying to separate it, they are ( “/” , “&” , “?” , “#”)

 

  • /  - Character serves as a path separator within the URL, much like it does in standard web URLs. Separates the main deep link path ( /sf/) from the specific action or page you're targeting.

  • ? – Act as the separator between the base URL and parameters (To recall parameters please refer to the point no 3)

 

  • & -  Acts as a separator between different parameters or key-value pairs within a URL.

 

  • # - Act as an anchor in the URL, which helps to direct the user to a specific section or element within the page. 

Configured Deeplink :

– Straight Navigation to Personal Data

 

Further granular navigation to Personal Information Detail Page.

Further, you can flip (or) change the values as per your navigation requirements.

entry.title: SAP User Feedback Day 2025: Putting Customers and end users at the Center of AI-driven Innovation
entry.content:
Delivering exceptional User Experience is the result of an ever-evolving journey fueled by insights gained from our customers and end users. SAP User Feedback Day 2025 embodied our commitment to listen, learn, and collaboratively shape a future where AI plays a pivotal role in redefining work processes.

AI: The Driving Force Behind Innovation

In today’s fast-paced world, AI is revolutionizing the way we operate—transforming learned patterns and optimizing workflows while empowering humans as the ultimate decision-makers. SAP User Feedback Day embraced this theme, inviting customers and end users to engage in AI-focused dialogues and understand its impact on real-world applications within our products.

  • Batch Release Hub Digital Assistant
  • Joule as a Project Assistant (for Non-Professional Services industry)
  • AI-driven resilient supply chain (IBP)

Employing diverse methods like interviews, usability testing, and moderated discussions, the business users were able to explore how AI can support them in their everyday tasks and provide meaningful feedback crucial for future product iterations.

In addition to the User Research, business users had the opportunity to explore six booths to dive deeper into what AI can do for them and how their feedback shapes SAP’s products.

SAP’s objective remains the same: empower users with efficient AI tools that enrich their experience and facilitate success. Engaging face-to-face with end users is an invaluable experience, reflecting our collective journey to tackle today’s challenges and anticipate tomorrow’s solutions. The customers and their end users explored AI's future potential through innovation workshops on the second day of the event, igniting anticipation for forthcoming developments.

Participants explored challenges and opportunities within SAP products, offering valuable feedback on GenUI's potential impacts on their roles and organizations. Engaging in brainstorming, foresight exercises, and collaborative discussions, attendees contributed to defining the future of SAP's user experiences.

This interactive session encouraged participants to share their current AI experiences and identify key opportunities where AI could address pressing challenges. Through collaborative brainstorming, attendees envisioned future states and crafted a "vision journey," discussing actionable steps needed to prepare for this AI-driven future. Both workshops were instrumental in harnessing collective intelligence to drive innovation and enhance user experiences.

Listening and collaborating with our users, we gained many invaluable insights on which we now can start to act. SAP User Feedback Day once again proved our commitment to customers is never fleeting—we pledge ongoing engagement to translate feedback into actionable improvements. The insights drive tangible benefits, refining our products to meet and exceed user aspirations.

Customer Voices

Basically we are partners, we are committed to SAP solutions, we are very satisfied with the performance right know and the better SAP gets, the better we are getting.”

SAP remains dedicated to leveraging AI’s capabilities while prioritizing human expertise, crafting products that deliver unmatched value and satisfaction. entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - Templates Best Practices
entry.content:
This article is part of a blog series on Dashboard Design BestPractices, created to assist you in designing and building meaningful dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud.
Click here to open the Dashboard Design Best-Practices blog series hub page in a new window. 

Blog Content

This blog illustrates where to find the template, a step-by-step description of how to customize it and a step-by-step explanation of how to create a logic group from scratch.

 

Where to find the Template?

Find all information about the template in this blog.
 
Here 's a sample story created with the template in just a few clicks.
In the next chapter, you will learn how to customize the template and quickly achieve your desired goal.

 

Template Customization

 Step-by Step description how to:
  1. Add Content to Placeholders 
  2. Remove Placeholders and delete Sections or Widgets 
  3. Adjust Page Content 

 

1. Add Content to Placeholders

Select the button in the placeholder and choose the model you want to use in the dialog that appears. 

 

Add desired measures and dimensions.

 

A specific chart type is predefined for each placeholder. 
However, this can be changed in the Builder Panel.

 

2. Remove Placeholders and delete Sections or Widgets 

To remove a placeholder, select the placeholder, select the three dots and
choose "Remove" from the context menu. Due to the underlying container structure,
the remaining content adapts automatically.

 

To delete an entire section within the template, you can also use the option to delete it from the outline. 
The layout automatically adjusts after deletion.

 

3. Add Page Content

There are various ways to add more content to the page.The easiest way is to copy and paste existing content and then adapt it. 

Step-by Step Example: Copy and Paste a Single Chart in a Logic Group

  • In the outline, select the panel with the chart that you want to copy

 

  • Use either the keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + C” on Windows or “Command + C” on Mac, or the Copy function in the toolbar.
  • In the outline, select the section where you want to paste the content.

 

  • To paste, use either the keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + V” on Windows or “Command + V” on Mac, or the Paste function in the toolbar.

After content has been added, you can adjust it in the builder or styling panel.

Example 2:

Step-by Step Example: Copy Existing Logic Group

  • Select the panel with the logic group that you want to copy, then use the copy functions as described in Example 1.

 

  • Select the section where you want to paste the logic group,
    then use the paste functions as described in Example 1.

 

 

The FlowLayoutPanel automatically positions the added Logic Group downwards.
Remember, while the contents of the individual sections, which are on one level, are arranged from top to bottom, the presentation in the outline is reversed. Therefore, what is at the top visually is at the bottom in the outline structure.

 

 

 

Build a Logic Group from Scratch

Step 1: Create New Story

  • Go to your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.
  • Select Canvas.

Step 2: Add a Panel to the Page

  • In the toolbar, select the add button > Containers > Panel.

  •  

    In the styling panel, adopt the values for Size and Position:
    Width = 100% I  Height = 400px I  Left = 0px I  Right = auto I  Top = 0px I  Bottom = auto

 

Step 3: Add Card Panel in Existing Panel

  • Add an additional panel to the first panel. 
  • To use the Fiori Horizon theme for the panel, enter “card” under CSS Class Name in the styling panel.

    Set the Size and Position:
    Width = auto I  Height = auto I  Left = 16px I  Right = 16px I  Top = 16px I  Bottom = 8px

 

 

Step 4: Add Panel for Logic Group Header

  • Add an additional panel for the header text to the previous panel.
  • To get a visual separator, in the CSS Class Name field in the styling panel, add “logic-group__header”.
  • Set Size and Position: Width = auto I  Height = 48px I  Left = 0px I  Right = 0px I  Top = 0px I  
    Bottom = auto 
  • Set Corner Radius to 0px.

     

Step 5: Add Text Element to Header Panel

  • Choose Text and enter the name of your logic group.
  • To use the Fiori Horizon theme for the header text, in the CSS Class Name field in the styling panel,
    add “logic-group__title”.
  • Set Size and Position:
    Width = auto I  Height = auto I  Left = 16px I  Right = individually I  Top = 10px I  Bottom = 0px
     
     

 

Step 6: Add Flow Layout Panel for Content

  • Select Panel_2
  • Choose Containers > Flow Layout Panel.

 

 

  • In the styling panel, set Size and Position for the Flow Layout Panel:

    Width = auto I  Height = auto I  Left = 16px I  Right = 16px I  Top = 58px I  Bottom = 8px

 

Step 7: Add Chart Widget

  • Insert a chart widget into the flow layout panel.

 

  • Select chart type and define the measures and dimensions.

 

  • In the styling panel, set Size and Position:

    Width = 50% I  Height = 100%

 

Step 8: Copy and paste chart widget

  • Select the chart that you want to copy.

  • Use the Copy function in the toolbar or use the
    keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + C” on Windows or “Command + C” on Mac.

 

  • Select the flow layout panel where you want to paste the chart to.

 

  • Use the Paste function in the toolbar or use the keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + V” on Windows or “Command + V” on Mac.

 

  • Select chart type and define the measures and dimensions.

 

 

If you wanted to create a logic group with two chart widgets, this is the result.

 
To add more charts to the logic group, repeat the steps, but you may need to adjust the width of each chart as needed. For example, if you have three widgets side by side, use 33% for every chart widget.

 

Result

 Congratulations! Your logic group should now look something like this.

entry.title: SAP 分析云 – 使用故事模版的最佳实践
entry.content:
本文系“仪表盘设计最佳实践”博客系列之一，旨在协助用户借助 SAP 分析云设计并构建具有业务价值的仪表盘。   

 请点击此处，在新窗口中打开“仪表盘设计最佳实践”博客系列总览页。 

博客内容   

本文将详细说明以下内容：   

  1. 模板获取位置；   
  2. 模板自定义的分步操作指南；   
  3. 从零开始构建逻辑组的分步说明。 

在哪里查找模板？ 

请在此博客中查阅有关该 Horizon 模板的全部信息。

下方展示的是仅通过数次点击、利用该模板快速生成的示例故事。 

下一章节将为您详细说明如何对模板进行定制，以便迅速达成您的预期目标。 

模板自定义   

以下为分步操作指引，帮助您完成以下任务：   

  1. 向占位符添加内容；   
  2. 移除占位符并删除相应区段或微件；   
  3. 调整页面内容。 

1.向占位符添加内容；   

选中占位符中的按钮，在随后弹出的对话框内选择您想要使用的模型。 

添加所需的度量和维度。 

每个占位符均已预设特定统计图类型，但您仍可在“生成器”面板中按需更改。 

2. 移除占位符并删除区段或微件 

如需移除占位符，请先选中该占位符，点击右上角“···”图标，然后在上下文菜单中选择“删除”。由于底层采用自适应容器结构，其余内容将自动调整布局。 

如需删除模板中的整个区段，亦可通过“大纲”面板执行删除操作；删除后，布局将自动适配调整。 

3. 添加页面内容   

可通过多种方式向页面补充内容，最简单的方法是复制并粘贴现有内容，随后按需调整。 

分步示例：在逻辑组中复制并粘贴单个统计图   

  • 在“大纲”中，选中包含待复制统计图的面板。 

  • 使用快捷键（Windows 按 Ctrl + C，Mac 按 Command + C）或工具栏中的“复制”功能完成复制。随后，在“大纲”中选中您希望粘贴内容的目标区块。 
  • 粘贴时，请使用快捷键（Windows 按 Ctrl + V，Mac 按 Command + V）或工具栏中的“粘贴”功能。   

内容添加完毕后，您可在生成器或样式设置面板中对其进行进一步调整。 

示例 2：   

分步说明：复制现有逻辑组   

  • 选中包含待复制逻辑组的面板，随后按照示例 1 所述方法执行复制操作。 

  • 选中您希望粘贴该逻辑组的区块，随后按照示例 1 所述方法执行粘贴操作。 

FlowLayoutPanel 会自动将新增的逻辑组向下排列。请注意：在同一层级的各个区块中，页面上的实际显示顺序为自上而下，但在“大纲”中的排列顺序则相反——即页面上位于最上方的内容，在大纲结构中显示在最下方。 

从零开始构建逻辑组 

步骤 1：创建新故事   

  • 登录您的 SAP Analytics Cloud 租户，选择“画布”。 

步骤 2：向页面添加面板   

  • 在工具栏中，依次选择“添加”按钮 > “容器” > “面板”。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将尺寸与位置参数设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = 100%  、高度 = 400px 、左侧 = 0px 、右侧 = auto 、顶部 = 0px 、底部 = auto 

步骤 3：在现有面板中添加卡片面板   

  • 在第一层面板内再添加一块面板。   
  • 若需为此面板应用 Fiori Horizon 主题，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”处输入 card。  
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto 、高度 = auto 、左侧 = 16px 、右侧 = 16px 、顶部 = 16px 、底部 = 8px 

步骤 4：添加逻辑组标题面板   

  • 在上一步所建面板内再添加一块新面板，用于承载标题文本。   
  • 若需呈现视觉分隔效果，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”字段中输入 logic-group__header。   
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = 48px  、左侧 = 0px  、右侧 = 0px  、顶部 = 0px  、底部 = auto   
  • 圆角半径设为 0px。 

步骤 5：向标题面板添加文本元素   

  • 选择“文本”并输入逻辑组名称。若需为标题文本应用 Fiori Horizon 主题，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”字段中输入 logic-group__title。   
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = auto  、左侧 = 16px  、右侧 = 自定义  、顶部 = 10px  、底部 = 0px 

步骤 6：添加流式布局面板   

  • 选中 Panel_2，依次选择“容器” > “流式布局面板”。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将流式布局面板的尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = auto  、左侧 = 16px  、右侧 = 16px  、顶部 = 58px  、底部 = 8px 

步骤 7：添加统计图微件   

  • 在流式布局面板中插入一个统计图微件。 

  • 选择统计图类型，并为统计图定义所需的度量与维度。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = 50%  、高度 = 100% 

步骤 8：复制并粘贴统计图微件   

  • 选中需复制的统计图，使用工具栏中的“复制”功能，或按快捷键（Windows：Ctrl + C；Mac：Command + C）。 

  • 选中您希望粘贴统计图的流式布局面板。 

  • 请使用工具栏中的“粘贴”功能，或通过快捷键（Windows：Ctrl + V；Mac：Command + V）完成粘贴。 

  • 请再次选择统计图类型，并设定所需的度量与维度。 

若您需构建一个包含两个统计图微件的逻辑组，至此即可完成。 

如需在逻辑组中继续添加更多统计图，请重复上述步骤，并根据需要调整每张统计图的宽度。例如，若需并排展示三张统计图，请将每张统计图的宽度均设为 33%。 

结果 

恭喜！至此，您的逻辑组应已呈现类似下图所示的效果。

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP SuccessFactors, as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

In this first post, we’ll look at the latest cross-suite UX innovations, coming from Joule, SAP Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start.

Before we get started: if you haven’t already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q1/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q2 2025.
  • SAP Sapphire Innovation Guide – SAP Business AI.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we’ll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule stand-alone: Joule for Consultants
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Joule Agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 1: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule “Show me sales commission by agend for model bike sales”, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 1, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 1 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as “What is the total revenue for Q1?” or “Show me sales by region in 2025”.
  • Comparative analysis, such as “Compare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?”
  • Time series analysis, such as “Show me sales by month” or “Show the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months”.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as “Show me top 5 sales by store” or “List the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales”.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 2 shows what this looks like.

 

Figure 2: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking “How many languages does Joule support”. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with “Joule currently supports eleven language officially” and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document “Joule Multi Language Support” is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button “+ New Conversation” at the top, followed by a section “Active” with two conversations and a sectin “Expired” with four. The bottom contains a link to “Settings” and on to “AI Notice”.

You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on “New Conversation”. The old conversation will be listed in the “Active” section, as you can see in Figure 2. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the “Expired” section, as shown in Figure 2. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 3.

Figure 3: Joule expanded to full-screen mode, showing the conversation history sidebar and the chat side by side. Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Using the Joule Web Client.

Use Joule in 11 Languages

Figure 3 shows that you can ask Joule which languages it supports, and it will answer with the list of 11 languages. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portugese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

Joule Stand-alone – Joule for Consultants

In addition to providing Joule embedded in our products, we have a design pattern called Joule stand-alone, which we use for Joule for Consultants. With this pattern, Joule can be started directly, without first opening an SAP product and then opening Joule via the icon in the shell header. Joule stand-alone is opened in full screen, as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 4: Joule for Consultants using the Joule stand-alone pattern. Alt-Text: Joule full-screen, with one active conversation “Can you explaine about SAP Clean Core”, followed by a comprehensive answer, and scrolling options for reading the entire text”.

By supporting this pattern, people can open up Joule for Consultants directly and start asking questions about implementing or extending SAP products. Since in this case Joule is stand-alone, as the name suggests, the conversations you have there are not visible in the Joule instance that is embedded in our products, and vice-versa.

Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams

How often have you been in a chat with a colleague and needed to find some information from an SAP system? Up until now this would involve you leaving the chat, going to a different window and navigating to the right SAP application to get what were looking for.

Now, you can chat directly with Joule in Microsoft Teams, use Joule in Microsoft Teams and Microsoft Teams Mobile as an app, and ask Joule questions directly in Microsoft 365 Copilot. To get an idea of how powerful this is, watch this video:

To get started, have a look at the documentation:

  • Integrating Joule with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Joule Agents

We are bringing SAP Business AI to the next level via Joule Agents, that can autonomously plan and execute multi-step workflows.

Why do I include this in a section on user experience updates? Aren’t Joule Agents a back-end thing? Well… the reason is simple: Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests. This means that the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

Joule Agents can be triggered from Joule directly, or embedded within applications. These four marketing videos show you examples of agents available today:

  • Finance: Dispute Resolution Agent (1:38 minutes)
  • Procurement: Sourcing Agent (1:48 minutes)
  • Sales and services: Account Planning Agent (1:24 minutes)
  • Human Resources: Performance and Goals Agent (1:34 minutes)

This example for customer service agents goes into more detail:

  • CX Agents (in SAP Discovery Center).

For a general overview of Joule Agents, have a look here:

  • Joule Agents on sap.com.
  • AI Agents in Action (blog post).
  • Envision the Future of Generative AI with SAP's AI Agents (blog post).
  • How SAP’s AI Agent Architecture Enables Unprecedented Automation and Decision Augmentation (blog post by Philipp Herzig).

Product-specific capabilities

In addition to the above generic capabilities, our products provide a large number of Joule skills for getting your work done more efficiently, as well as a handful of the new agents discussed above. For a comprehensive overview of Joule capabilities, including product-specific skills available today, here’s where to go:

  • Joule Capabilities (a 484 page (!) PDF document from July 11th, 2025, including a list of What’s New)
  • Joule Capabilities (online documentation)

Customer-specific Joule skills

You can now build your own Joule skills using Joule Studio, which has now been made generally available. Read Michael Ameling’s overview blog post:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation

Joule on Mobile Devices – now for SAP SuccessFactors too

Joule has been available via SAP Mobile Start since Q1/2025 (as announced in this blog post), and is now also available directly from within the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app, supporting these three patterns:

  • Transactional: Joule can handle tasks like requesting time off, updating contact information, and even deleting phone numbers, directly within the chat interface.
  • Navigational: Joule can guide users to specific pages within the app based on their requests, such as directing them to where they can assign team goals.
  • Informational: Joule can access documentation and knowledge bases to answer questions about company policies, HR guidelines, and other relevant information, providing summaries and links to related resources.

Figure 5 shows two examples of the transactional pattern plus one example of the informational pattern (“Can I use my private car for my business trip?”).

 

Figure 5: Examples of Joule on the SuccessFactors Mobile App. Alt Text: The image shows three examples: The first shows the response to the request by a manager “View time off approval”, with the details of one request, including the employee's name, the time-off period, and the type of time-off (vacation). The user can view the details, approve, or decline the request. The second screen shows a conversation where the user asks if they can use their private car for a business trip, and the system responds that they can, providing details on the reimbursement policy. The third screen shows the user requesting one day of vacation leave on March 3, 2025. The system confirms the request and provides the details of the leave, including the start and end times, and the date the user will return to work.

Find out more here:

  • Say Hi to Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile, Powered by SAP Build - Part 1: Unlocking AI for HR)
  • Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile: Getting Things Done with AI...
  • Documentation: Joule Available in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile - May 2025

Further information on Joule

If you want an overview of what’s new, or want to set up Joule in your landscape, have a look at the documentation:

  • Joule documentation (including What’s New, What is Joule?, integration guide)
  • What is Joule? PDF file

For an overview of what is planned, have a look at the road map for Joule in the SAP Road Map Explorer:

  • Joule Road Map.

 

SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone users and administrators benefit from these recent innovations:

  • New Side navigation for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.
  • SAPUI5 version preview.
  • Mobile Start supports Work Zone, advanced edition.

New Side Navigation

As I announced in April, in my blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), we are introducing some design updates to all our products in the SAP Business Suite to further increase consistency, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises. One of these is the introduction of a navigation menu on the left side of the screen.

SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, is the first product to support this new design. Figure 6 shows what it looks like when the navigation menu is expanded, while Figure 7 shows it collapsed.

Figure 6: Side navigation expanded for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: A screen showing a SAP Build Work Zone screen with a navigation menu on the left with four entries “Central Procurement”, “Global Support”, “My IT Experience” (selected), and “Self Services”. On the right various cards are shown in a section “Employee Information”.

 

Figure 7: Side navigation collapsed for SAP Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: similar to Figure 6, but with the navigation menu on the left collapsed to the width of an icon, with four icons shown representing the four navigation options.

SAPUI5 Version Preview

We have introduced a new feature that allows administrators to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone, two weeks before they are adopted in the productive environment.  Until now, the latest SAPUI5 versions were automatically adopted in production environments, which limited opportunities for early evaluation ahead of deployment.

By enabling the preview setting on specific non-productive sites, administrators can assess compatibility and performance with the upcoming version. This controlled testing environment helps identify and address potential issues, reducing the likelihood of disruptions in production. After the two-week preview period, the RTC version becomes the default, aligning all sites with the latest stable release.

When looking at the sites in the site directory, those sites for which the preview is switched on are indicated clearly, as shown in Figure X.

Figure 8: Site directory with a site where preview is turned on. Alt Text: the image shows a card from the site directory for a site called “Preview SAPUI5 Demo” with a green badge containing the text “SAPUI5 Preview Enabled”.

Read more about this feature in this blog post:

  • Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone.

SAP Mobile Start Supports SAP Work Zone, Advanced Edition

When using SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you can now access your Workspaces or Feed Updates. As with the standard edition, your native and web apps are available within the Apps Screen of SAP Mobile Start, as well as in your Favorites Section on the Start Screen, based on your individual selection. 

Tasks and Notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, are also integrated into SAP Mobile Start: they are shown next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center. Figure 9 shows an example with notifications from the advanced edition.

This integration is automatically available to customers with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition or SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone if the SAP Mobile Start toggle is enabled in the Site Manager.

Figure 9: SAP Mobile Start notification center with notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Alt Text: A list of two notifications: “Leave Request”, with a red text “Important” and “2 weeks ago”, and “Invite to Worskpace”, with text “Mustaq Ahmmed has invited you to join the workspace “Help & Support Workspace” and “2 weeks ago”.

 

Note that SAP Mobile Start is not the successor app for the SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app. Find out more here:

  • Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update.

 

SAP Mobile Start

Beyond providing Joule natively for mobile devices, SAP Mobile Start has recently introduced a number of user experience improvements with their 2.2 and 2.3 releases. In addition to supporting SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, as described above, the main new features are:

  • Completed To-Dos are now displayed too (see Figure 10).

  • The news tile can now also include images (see Figure 10).
  • News feeds that require authentication are supported now.
  • Design updates such as enhanced navigation bar for Apple iPad and a new fresher design for monitoring details on Apple Watch.

Figure 10: On the left, SAP Mobile Start showing completed To-Dos, on the right showing news with an image. The first one shows Maria Smith requested 180 days maternity leave, the second one that Quality Manager Donna Moore requested €47,600 spend. The right shows the start page, with a section Monitoring apps at the top, with two cards, followed by the News section, with one card listing two news items, the first of which has an image.

entry.title: My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?
entry.content:
The 2508 release of My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition introduces a range of new delivered and beta features, along with UX enhancements designed to elevate your overall experience. In this blog, I’ll walk you through these updates and what they mean for you. 

My Home offers immediate access to key business insights, supports efficient management of tasks and situations, and allows you to organize your favorite pages and apps to streamline daily operations. The 2508 release builds on this foundation by further enhancing each of these areas. 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release My Home

 

One of the standout additions is the new personalized salutation bar, which greets every business user upon entering My Home. This feature not only creates a more personalized experience but also helps users quickly orient themselves within SAP S/4HANA. Now enable communication scenario SAP_COM_0887 and let business users see what’s next on their calendar at a glance. Additionally, the salutation bar consolidates all of My Home’s global actions in one convenient place—it enables users to easily add content, quickly access My Home settings, and discover the latest feature introduced in the 2508 release: Recap. 

My Home 2508 Salutation bar

 

The Recap feature introduced in the My Home 2508 release is designed to save time by helping business users stay on top of key items that have emerged since their last login. It highlights high-priority information, enabling users to quickly focus on what matters most. By surfacing relevant updates and simplifying daily tasks, Recap reduces manual effort and helps users catch up efficiently—so they can shift their attention to higher-value activities. 

My Home 2508 Recap of Tasks

 

 My Home 2508 Recap of Insights

 

Recap analyzes changes in My Home data over the past 24 hours, keeping business users informed about new tasks, situations, and updates to app, tile, and insights card access. It also provides visual comparisons of insights cards, making it easy to quickly and intuitively understand what has changed during your absence. 

The Salutation Bar also allows business users to easily add content to My Home from a centralized location. But that’s just the beginning—it now supports AI-assisted content addition, enabling users to add Insights cards using natural language. Users can also preview Insights cards during the addition process to ensure data accuracy and consistency. 

My Home 2508 AI-assisted Smart Personalization Insights Card Addition

With the 2508 release, business users can take advantage of a new Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition feature that enables the addition of applications using natural language. This significantly streamlines the process of adding applications, saving time and offering a more intuitive, click-efficient experience— which is particularly valuable for first-time or occasional users. The feature also enhances transparency by displaying application descriptions and real-time KPIs for dynamic tiles, providing immediate operational context. 

My Home 2508 Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition

My Home serves as the central hub for all your tasks, applications, and information. In the 2508 release, improvements have been made with the Recap and AI-assisted content addition features. Additionally, administrators are now empowered to deliver timely, targeted updates directly to business users via the My Home centralized news feed. 

With the addition of the Mange News application, administrators can create news articles to be displayed on My Home. They can categorize, target and manage the visibility of the news. Tailoring communication to your organization needs helps create a more informed and connected workforce. This in turn enhances business users’s performance by equipping them with the information needed to make smarter, faster decisions. 

My Home Manage News Application

 

 

My Home 2508 News Article Creation

 

My Home 2508 Critical News Article

We hope everyone enjoys the new features of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release – stay tuned for more updates! The Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition in My Home, highlighted in this article, are now available for Beta Testing with the 2508 release. At SAP, we’re committed to delivering the best experience possible, which is why we’re inviting you to join our Beta Testing Program. By participating, you’ll get early access to these features, have the chance to share your feedback, and help us fine-tune them before the official launch. Your input will play a key role in shaping the quality and usability of these new capabilities. 

Also, If you are interested in hearing about the latest innovations in SAP Cloud ERP, please join our Public Cloud Practitioner Forum in which SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers share best practices and provide feedback to the SAP development teams about new functionality.
